post_text: Welcome to a new school year! As part of our school district safety plan, we have worked to improve building security and you will notice some changes to our entry procedures at most of the buildings. At the High School, the main entry will be the side door facing the bus loop (A2). At the Middle School, the Main Office was moved to the Guidance area and the entry way was expanded. You will now be able to drop off materials or forgotten items in the vestibule between the two sets of doors at each of the buildings (except Center School). Each school has established drop off procedures and times that the Principals have communicated through their newsletters. We ask for your cooperation in helping us to maintain the security of our school buildings by not providing access to the building to anybody waiting behind you. I wish all of our students a wonderful year and an exciting Back-to-School week! Sincerely, Dr. MacLeod

Introducing A Facebook Guide for Educators and Community Leaders
Today, we are releasing the Facebook for Educators and Community Leaders Guide , a new resource that helps adults be supportive partners so that teens make safe, smart and responsible choices throughout the online world.

Today‚Äôs teens were born into a digital world. They are connecting, sharing and learning through the latest advances in technology. This is creating a vibrant world full of interactivity and learning, where young people make new things and connect in ways that enrich their lives in the classroom and in their communities.

By all accounts, teens are mindful of how to behave and interact using social media. Still, the adults in teen‚Äôs lives ‚Äì the parents, the educators, the community leaders -- need to be supportive partners, assisting teens as they navigate safety, privacy, digital literacy and citizenship. That means that they need to understand the digital world ‚Äì and Facebook, in particular.

The Facebook for Educators and Community Leaders Guide provides resources to help you do that. The guide includes a focus on:
Digital Hygiene and Digital Citizenship ‚Äì The guide features expert resources from the Family Online Safety Institute‚Äôs Platform for Good initiative as well as resources from WiredSafety on how to engender digital citizenship and literacy among teens.Mobile ‚Äì ConnectSafely.org provides guidance on the impact of mobile technology on safety, so that adults can consider the best ways to guide teens.Developing Guidelines ‚Äì Many organizations are developing social media policies. Our partners at Edutopia ‚Äì The George Lucas Educational Foundation -- have provided guidance on how to develop these policies and guidelines, for the classroom and for community organizations.
Thank you to the many organizations who helped us develop and distribute this guide, including the Family Online Safety Institute, WiredSafety, ConnectSafely.org, the Girl Scouts of Northern California , the PACER Center , Edutopia, the U.S. Council of Catholic Bishops , Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America , and Cartoon Network‚Äôs Stop Bullying: Speak Up initiative .

Finally, thank you to author and parenting expert Rosalind Wiseman ‚Äì author of the newly released book, Masterminds and Wingmen ‚Äì for her tips for adults on how to engage with teens in the social media world. Take a look at her Facebook Story released today.

Safety is an ongoing conversation where everyone plays a role ‚Äì parents, educators, teens, policy makers, and all members of the community. We hope you take advantage of the guide and stay tuned to the Facebook Safety Page to participate in the conversation.

--The Facebook Safety Team

___________

Support for the Facebook for Educators and Community Leaders Guide

‚ÄúGovernment and responsible corporate citizens alike have an interest in teens being smart and safe when using social media.¬† But it is fundamental that parents understand social media and their teen‚Äôs use of social media and that they help their teens make safe and informed choices.¬† ¬†The Facebook for Educators & Community Leaders Guide is a guide to help parents, teachers, and community leaders do just that.‚Äù
--Wisconsin Attorney General J.B. Van Hollen, President, National Association of Attorneys General

‚ÄúPACER‚Äôs National Bullying Prevention Center hears from thousands of students and their parents every year who have been bullied. With this excellent guide by Facebook, parents and educators can take an active role in helping to keep students safe from bullying while they‚Äôre online. Social media has allowed for many new and exciting opportunities for children and teens, but parents and educators need to become active participants in order to encourage responsible digital citizenship and safe online practices.‚Äù
--Paula F. Goldberg, Executive Director, PACER Center

"We're seeing more and more schools and districts create social media guidelines to help teens and educators navigate the digital world in a safe and effective way. This new guide, developed by Facebook, comes at a perfect time for parents, educators, and community leaders."
--Elana Leoni, Director of Social Media Strategy and Marketing, Edutopia

‚ÄúReligious communities are about relationships. So is Facebook. We‚Äôve found our collaboration with Facebook on developing sound, holistic and ethical standards to be particularly helpful.¬†According to the latest research, teens understand privacy and how to control their information online. From religious leaders to parents, the adults in our teens' lives need to be just as fluent as teens are in order to provide guidance.¬†This new guide, we hope, is the first of many tools that will encourage religious leaders, parents and others concerned about our children‚Äôs welfare to utilize Facebook as a positive force for young people.‚Äù
--Helen Osman, Secretary of Communications, US Conference of Catholic Bishops

"This guide is both practical and timely. ¬†Educators and youth leaders are keen to find ways to safely and productively engage teens in social media. ¬†The resources in this guide will help steer kids away from negative behaviors, while directing them to the best uses of Facebook and encourage good digital citizenship."
--Stephen Balkam

"Our teens turn to their educators and community leaders for guidance on important life issues. This simple and comprehensive guide makes it easy to understand and provide guidance to teens about using social media to lead, become empowered and improve their world, safely, effectively and securely."
--Parry Aftab, Esq., Executive Director, WiredSafety.org

"We look forward to adding the "Facebook for Educator's and Community Leader's Guide" to Cartoon Network's STOP BULLYING:SPEAK UP list of resources. ¬†The new guide offers concise information to adults working with young people; providing clear, accurate direction on the appropriate use of social media."
--Alice Cahn, Vice President of Social Responsibility, Cartoon Network
